node.title: Crystal plasticity domain mostly moving as rigid body
node.bodyText:
Hello all,
I am working to validate the crystal plasticity module against a shear strain problem a colleague calculated with another code. The BCs are a high strain rate on the top, 20 MPa pressure on top, no x displacement in the lower left ,and no y displacement on lower right, as shown in the first image below. What ends up happening is the lower left pin pulls away from the rest of the domain, as shown in the second image. The material properties and BCs nearly match the problem I am validating against, the only exception is that the problem I am validating against uses Periodic BCs. When I apply periodic BCs to the displacement variables then all stress/strain is resolved and there is no evolution.
I have not seen any example problems using Crystal Plasticity in MOOSE that uses periodic BCs, are they simply inappropriate when solving for displacement? Does anyone have any insight or suggestions about what could be causing the overall behavior I am seeing?
Thanks,
Floyd

node.title: How to include Python.h in MOOSE code?
node.bodyText:
I can easily include Python.h in gcc environment like this:
File runpy.cpp
#include "/usr/include/python3.10/Python.h"
int main()
{
  Py_Initialize();
  PyRun_SimpleString("print('Hello world!')");
  PyFinalize();
  return 0;
}
Input in shell:
gcc runpy.cpp -o runpy -I/usr/include/python3.10 -lpython3.10
./runpy

It will certainly return:
Hello world!

However, how to compile Python.h in MOOSE codes?
When I try to input include "/usr/include/python3.10/Python.h" in my source code. As I build
conda activate moose
make

The shell will return errors like:
Checking if header needs updating: /home/sjtu/projects/moose/framework/include/base/MooseRevision.h...
Creating Unity Directory /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_couplewithpy/build/unity_src
Creating Unity /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_couplewithpy/build/unity_src/problem_Unity.C
Rebuilding symlinks in /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_couplewithpy/build/header_symlinks
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_couplewithpy/build/unity_src/problem_Unity.C...
In file included from /usr/include/python3.10/Python.h:8,
                 from /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_couplewithpy/src/problem/ExternalZidingyiQiujieqiChuanshuShujuProblem.C:10,
                 from /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_couplewithpy/build/unity_src/problem_Unity.C:2:
/usr/include/python3.10/pyconfig.h:3:12: fatal error: x86_64-linux-gnu/python3.10/pyconfig.h: No such file or directory
    3 | #  include <x86_64-linux-gnu/python3.10/pyconfig.h>
      |            ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
compilation terminated.
make: *** [/home/sjtu/projects/moose/framework/build.mk:151: /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_couplewithpy/build/unity_src/problem_Unity.x86_64-conda-linux-gnu.opt.lo] Error 1
I try to input ADDITIONAL_LIBS ="-I/usr/include/python3.10/ -lpython3.10", but it seems useless... It will return the same error...

What does the following return:
python3-config
For me, python3-config resides in my moose Conda environment. And so when I ask it what my include flags should be, I am provided with:
❯ python3-config --includes
-I/Users/milljm/conda3/envs/moose/include/python3.10 -I/Users/milljm/conda3/envs/moose/include/python3.10
I suppose that means the python interpreter I am using, should have its matching includes in the above location:
❯ file /Users/milljm/conda3/envs/moose/include/python3.10/python.h
/Users/milljm/conda3/envs/moose/include/python3.10/python.h: c program text, ASCII text
So perhaps the error you are receiving is mixing and matching different python includes (by hard coding a path to system python). Unless of course, you are actually wanting to use system python over the one supplied by the Conda moose environment?

You are right. It seems that there are two pythons for base and conda moose system, respectively...
I input
python3-config

It will return:
Usage: /home/sjtu/mambaforge3/bin/python3-config –prefix|--exec-prefix|--includes|--libs|--cflags|--ldflags|--extension-suffix|--help|--abiflags|--configdir|--embed
In the base environment, I input
python3-config --includes
It will return
-I/home/sjtu/mambaforge3/include/python3.10 -I/home/sjtu/mambaforge3/include/python3.10

However in conda MOOSE environment, the return is different. I input
conda activate moose
python3-config --includes

It will return a different directory
-I/home/sjtu/mambaforge3/envs/moose/include/python3.10 -I/home/sjtu/mambaforge3/envs/moose/include/python3.10

It seems that I should use system python rather than Conda moose environment... So what should I do? em...

There a several Makefile's in MOOSE which call for a Python interpreter. I think if you took a look at how we are determining where/what python includes there are available in the following Makefile, it might make more sense:
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/3a1efc798c7227ea5057590ab37e266f1201845b/framework/contrib/hit/Makefile
Edit:
Basically, instead of hard-coding a path to some version of Python, the logic in the above Makefile allows for code to use whatever python is currently being made available.

Milljm:
Could you tell me how to use this Makefile for including Python.h please?
In fact, I have never thought about the compiling process for MOOSE before. For solving this problem, recently, I have read the Makefile in user's app directory. In this Makefile, three mk files- build.mk, moose.mk and app.mk(not considering modules.mk) have been included. I insert echo command in these three files to trace what will happen after I make. And I found the shell will do (the name of user's MOOSE App is lianxi_mf in this example)
/home/sjtu/projects/moose/framework/scripts/get_repo_revision.py /home/sjtu/projects/moose/framework /home/sjtu/projects/moose/framework/include/base/MooseRevision.h MOOSE
$$(shell mkdir -p /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_mf/build/header_symlinks)
ln -sf /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_mf/include/base/lianxi_mfApp.h /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_mf/build/header_symlinks/lianxi_mfApp.h
ln -sf /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_mf/test/include/base/lianxi_mfTestApp.h /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_mf/build/header_symlinks/lianxi_mfTestApp.h
/home/sjtu/mambaforge3/envs/moose/libmesh/contrib/bin/libtool  ...(LOTS OF OPTIONS!)
/home/sjtu/mambaforge3/envs/moose/libmesh/contrib/bin/libtool  ...(LOTS OF OPTIONS!)
/home/sjtu/mambaforge3/envs/moose/libmesh/contrib/bin/libtool  ...(LOTS OF OPTIONS!)
/home/sjtu/mambaforge3/envs/moose/libmesh/contrib/bin/libtool  ...(LOTS OF OPTIONS!)
/home/sjtu/mambaforge3/envs/moose/libmesh/contrib/bin/libtool  ...(LOTS OF OPTIONS!)
/home/sjtu/mambaforge3/envs/moose/libmesh/contrib/bin/libtool  ...(LOTS OF OPTIONS!)
/home/sjtu/mambaforge3/envs/moose/libmesh/contrib/bin/libtool . ..(LOTS OF OPTIONS!)
some thing about  /scripts/write_appresource_file.py
/home/sjtu/mambaforge3/envs/moose/libmesh/contrib/bin/libtool . ..(LOTS OF OPTIONS!)

It seems that this Makefile(in the directory moose/framework/contrib/hit
) for Python interpreter you mentioned
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/3a1efc798c7227ea5057590ab37e266f1201845b/framework/contrib/hit/Makefile
have not work in the default MOOSE compiling process.
So how to use this Makefile for Python.h? Is there any tutorials?
I hope to receive your reply soon!
Sincerely yours
WANG Yihu

Jason Miller：
In fact, I do not understand the logic in the above Makefile. I try to change this Makefile
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/3a1efc798c7227ea5057590ab37e266f1201845b/framework/contrib/hit/Makefile
like this:

Change the pyconfig into the result of python3-config in the base environment instead of conda moose environment.
Add -I/home/sjtu/mambaforge3/include/python3.10 and -I/home/sjtu/mambaforge3/include/python3.10 at the end of the shell command.
Now the Makefile in https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/3a1efc798c7227ea5057590ab37e266f1201845b/framework/contrib/hit/Makefile
is changed into:

CXX ?= g++
UNAME := $(shell uname)

#pyconfig := python3-config
pyconfig :="Usage: /home/sjtu/mambaforge3/bin/python3-config --prefix|--exec-prefix|--includes|--libs|--cflags|--ldflags|--extension-suffix|--help|--abiflags|--configdir|--embed"
ifeq (, $(shell which $(pyconfig) 2>/dev/null))
	pyconfig := python-config
endif
cython := cython3
ifeq (, $(shell which $(cython) 2>/dev/null))
	cython := 'cython -3'
endif

ifeq ($(UNAME), Darwin)
	DYNAMIC_LOOKUP := -undefined dynamic_lookup
else
	DYNAMIC_LOOKUP :=
endif

$(info Building hit for python with $(pyconfig))

PYTHONPREFIX ?= `$(pyconfig) --prefix`
PYTHONCFLAGS ?= `$(pyconfig) --cflags`
HITCPP := hit.cpp

WASP_DIR           ?= $(abspath ../wasp/install)

# find the wasp libraries
lib_suffix := so
ifeq ($(shell uname -s),Darwin)
	lib_suffix := dylib
	wasp_LIBS         := $(shell find -E $(WASP_DIR)/lib -regex ".*/lib[a-z]+.$(lib_suffix)")
else
	wasp_LIBS         := $(wildcard $(WASP_DIR)/lib/libwasp*$(lib_suffix))
endif
wasp_LIBS         := $(notdir $(wasp_LIBS))
wasp_LIBS         := $(patsubst %.$(lib_suffix),%,$(wasp_LIBS))
wasp_LIBS         := $(patsubst lib%,-l%,$(wasp_LIBS))
ifeq ($(wasp_LIBS),)
  $(error WASP does not seem to be available. Make sure to either run scripts/update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh in your MOOSE directory, or set WASP_DIR to a valid WASP install)
endif

wasp_CXXFLAGS  += -I$(WASP_DIR)/include
wasp_LDFLAGS   += -Wl,-rpath,$(WASP_DIR)/lib -L$(WASP_DIR)/lib $(wasp_LIBS)

hit: main.cc parse.cc lex.cc braceexpr.cc braceexpr.h lex.h parse.h
	$(CXX) -std=c++17 $(wasp_CXXFLAGS) -g $(CXXFLAGS) $< parse.cc lex.cc braceexpr.cc -o $@ $(wasp_LDFLAGS) -I/usr/include/python3.10/ -lpython3.10

bindings: hit.so

hit.so: parse.cc lex.cc braceexpr.cc
	$(CXX) -std=c++17 $(wasp_CXXFLAGS) -w -fPIC -lstdc++ -shared -L$(PYTHONPREFIX)/lib $(PYTHONCFLAGS) $(DYNAMIC_LOOKUP) $^ $(HITCPP) -o $@ $(wasp_LDFLAGS) -I/usr/include/python3.10/ -lpython3.10

$(HITCPP): hit.pyx chit.pxd
	$(cython) -o $@ --cplus $< -I/usr/include/python3.10/ -lpython3.10

.PRECIOUS: $(HITCPP)

.PHONY: clean bindings

clean:
	rm -f hit hit.so
Now I input these
cd /home/sjtu/projects/moose/framework/contrib/hit/
rm -r hit
touch *./
conda activate moose
make

Now a new hit is generated!
I also add -I/home/sjtu/mambaforge3/include/python3.10 and -I/home/sjtu/mambaforge3/include/python3.10 in $(FRAMEWORK_DIR)/app.mk and $(FRAMEWORK_DIR)/build.mk like this discussion.
However, when I try to build in my MOOSE app. Input
cd home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_mf
conda activate moose
make

It failed again!
In file included from /usr/include/python3.10/Python.h:8,
                 from /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_mf/src/main.C:16:
/usr/include/python3.10/pyconfig.h:3:12: fatal error: x86_64-linux-gnu/python3.10/pyconfig.h: No such file or directory
    3 | #  include <x86_64-linux-gnu/python3.10/pyconfig.h>
      |            ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
compilation terminated.
make: *** [/home/sjtu/projects/moose/framework/build.mk:166: /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_mf/src/main.x86_64-conda-linux-gnu.opt.lo] Error 1

It seems that I do not understand how MOOSE import python...

Dear friends:
I have import Python.h in MOOSE code recently. Steps are shown below: (my username is sjtu)

Find head file Python.h and library file libpython3.10.so in the MOOSE environment(not base environment). These files' directories in my computer are /home/sjtu/mambaforge3/envs/moose/include/python3.10/Python.h and /home/sjtu/mambaforge3/envs/moose/lib/libpython3.10.so
Modify makefiles to add -I, -L, -l options. I add -I/home/sjtu/mambaforge3/envs/moose/include/python3.10/ -L/home/sjtu/mambaforge3/envs/moose/lib/ -lpython3.10 to app.mk and build.mk directly as shown in #26504
Input #include "/home/sjtu/mambaforge3/envs/moose/include/python3.10/Python.h" to your MOOSE C++ code.
Input these test code to your MOOSE C++ code.

Py_Initialize();
PyRun_SimpleString("print('Hello world!')");
PyFinalize();

This can be made in MOOSE environment in my computer successfully.
Certainly, this method is not perfect. It is not recommended to modify files in MOOSE framework  app.mk and build.mk. There might be environment variable for linking Python.h and  libpython3.10.so in the MOOSE environment instead of hard-coding a path.

You would want to modify your applications app.mk Makefile (and not the one in MOOSE) to link to what-ever-is you need from python3-config --cflags. I was only demonstrating how MOOSE makes use of some of Python's libraries by showing you the hit parser Makefile as an example, which makes use of python3-config.

node.title: FluidProperties module: locate out-of-range node during linear iterations
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I have a simulation (based on PorousFlow) which uses the FluidProperties module and tabulated properties for pure water. At a point, it does not converge:
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "tabulated_water95", of type "TabulatedBicubicFluidProperties".
Temperature 1643.76 is outside the range of tabulated temperature (273.17, 1400).


This value (1643.76) is way beyond the common values I have after convergence. I am wondering how to locate the node having this issue. Please, any suggestion?
Javier

Hello
The best way is probably to output the fluid properties on FAILED and locate the area using the exodus output.
You can use the FluidPropertiesMaterialPT for example to compute fluid properties as material properties. Then in that object you can set the output parameters to output to exodus
Note that returning an error for out of range is not what we should be doing here. We created the solution Invalid interface to avoid crashing simulations on out of range errors.

Hello Guillaume,
Many thanks! I had missed FluidPropertiesMaterialPT.
Also, I see that SolutionInvalidInterface is not in the version in our cluster. Will update it to see if/how that helps now

I don't know if the interface is used in the fluid properties.
But it should be used so we can change that if you see it s not

Ok I checked, even in the latest moose it's still using a custom error behavior instead of the solutionInvalidityInterface.
However, you can pass the error_on_out_of_bounds parameter as false to let it continue with the solve and a bad temperature. Then you can use the material property output to see where it happened

Ah! Many thanks for checking!
OK. I'll try this...
 
On Monday, January 15, 2024 03:11 CET, Guillaume Giudicelli ***@***.***> wrote:
 
 
Ok I checked, even in the latest moose it's still using a custom error behavior instead of the solutionInvalidityInterface.
However, you can pass the error_on_out_of_bounds parameter as false to let it continue with the solve and a bad temperature. Then you can use the material property output to see where it happened
—
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or unsubscribe.
You are receiving this because you authored the thread.Message ID: ***@***.***>[ { ***@***.***": "http://schema.org", ***@***.***": "EmailMessage", "potentialAction": { ***@***.***": "ViewAction", "target": "#26551 (reply in thread)", "url": "#26551 (reply in thread)", "name": "View Discussion" }, "description": "View this Discussion on GitHub", "publisher": { ***@***.***": "Organization", "name": "GitHub", "url": "https://github.com" } } ]***>

node.title: Broken peacock
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
Did anyone else ever suffer from a broken peakcock visualizer? Since day one of me using Moose, when switching between the tabs of peacock, the application occasionally break. You can see an example below:

After starting the application it looks like this (as it should):

In the terminal, I get the following errors:
QCssParser::parseColorValue: Specified color without alpha value but alpha given: 'rgb 111, 111, 111, 255'
QCssParser::parseColorValue: Specified color without alpha value but alpha given: 'rgb 180, 180, 180, 255'
QCssParser::parseColorValue: Specified color without alpha value but alpha given: 'rgb 111, 111, 111, 255'
QCssParser::parseColorValue: Specified color without alpha value but alpha given: 'rgb 111, 111, 111, 255'
QCssParser::parseColorValue: Specified color without alpha value but alpha given: 'rgb 180, 180, 180, 255'
QCssParser::parseColorValue: Specified color without alpha value but alpha given: 'rgb 111, 111, 111, 255'

Hello
I have seen these rgb messages before I think they are just warnings.
What platform are you using? Can you paste the output of the diagnostics script in moose/scripts ?
Guillaume

node.title: I'd like to generate a csv file with time dependent data of a certain variable in my input file but I don't know how.
node.bodyText:
I would like to generate a csv file that contains the 'vonmises_stress' parameter's value with respect to the timestep it was calculated on but I don't know how. This is my input file as of now:
[Mesh]

        [annular]

                type = AnnularMeshGenerator

                nr = 10

                rmin = 7.5

                rmax = 10.0

                nt = 40

        []

        [make3D]

                type = MeshExtruderGenerator

                extrusion_vector = '0 0 40'

                num_layers = 10

                bottom_sideset = 'bottom'

                top_sideset = 'top'

                input = annular

        []

[]



[GlobalParams]

        displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'

[]



[Variables]

        [./T]

                order = FIRST

                family = LAGRANGE

        [../]

[]



[AuxVariables]

        [temp]

        []

[]



[AuxKernels]

        [temperature_ramp]

                type = FunctionAux

                execute_on = TIMESTEP_BEGIN

                variable = temp

                function = 300+5*t

        []

[]



[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]

      [all]

        add_variables = true

        automatic_eigenstrain_names = true

        generate_output = 'vonmises_stress'

      []

[]



[Kernels]

        [./diffused]

                type = Diffusion

                variable = T

        [../]

        [./euler]

                type = ExampleTimeDerivative

                variable = T

                time_coefficient = 20.0

        [../]

[]



[BCs]

        [./inner]

                type = DirichletBC

                variable = T

                boundary = 'rmin'

                value = 573.15

        [../]

        [./outer]

                type = NeumannBC

                variable = T

                boundary = 'rmax'

                value = 0

        [../]

        [./x]

                type = DirichletBC

                variable = disp_x

                boundary = 'rmin'

                value = 0.0

        [../]

        [./y]

                type = DirichletBC

                variable = disp_y

                boundary = 'rmin'

                value = 0.0

        [../]

        [./z]

                type = DirichletBC

                variable = disp_z

                boundary = 'rmin'

                value = 0.0

        [../]

[]



[Materials]

        [elasticity]

                type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor

                youngs_modulus = 1e9

                poissons_ratio = 0.3

        []

        [stress]

                type = ComputeLinearElasticStress

        []

        [expansion]

                type = ComputeThermalExpansionEigenstrain

                temperature = temp

                thermal_expansion_coeff = 0.001

                stress_free_temperature = 300

                eigenstrain_name = thermal_expansion

        []

[]



[Executioner]

        type = Transient

        solve_type = NEWTON

        num_steps = 200

        dt = 1

[]



[Outputs]

                execute_on = 'timestep_end'

                exodus = true

                

                [./vonmises_stress_output]

                	type = CSV

    			execute_on = 'timestep_end'

    			file_base = 'vonmises_stress_output.csv'

                [../]

[]

My other problem is this: What I really want from this simulation is the volumetric stress data with respect to the timestep, so basically how the vol. stress varied with respect to passing time in the simulation but I can't find any relevant modules/kernels that would calculate that for me. If you could please suggest something that would be super helpful.
Thanks!

Hello
If you want the maximum or the integrated stress, look at postprocessors. In particular the ones performing reductions on material properties
By default, once you have set Outputs/csv=true, they will be output to CSV at each time step.
If you want the spatial distribution of the stress, then look at vector postprocessors. There is one that compute the local value of material properties and outputs it to CSV
Guillaume

node.title: Convergence Issue
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am facing a convergence issue while solving the problem. I'm not able to understand
I am using this
[Executioner]

Hello
The linear solves are not converging, so the nonlinear solves are also not converging.
SVD is not really meant for solving systems, we just use it to look at the singular values. Did you try a more classic preconditioner like LU?
Guillaume

node.title: _use_snes_vi_solver and _barrier

node.bodyText:
My guess is that the SNES VI solver should be imposing that constraining so we should not need to do it ourselves?
but @jiangwen84  will know for sure

@selarem your changes seem to be reasonable to me. When we initially implemented it, we only considered either using VI without barrier or using barrier without VI, did not think about combing these two.
Are you willing to make a PR to correct it? Please do not forget to add a regression test.

node.title: How to get crack location
node.bodyText: I use BreakMeshByBlockGenerator and CohesiveZoneMaster for simulating crack propagation, and I want to get the location of the crack in the process of crack propagation and crack width information, such as used within the fracture fluid is calculated. How can I get this information.
@recuero
@hugary1995

Are you planning to get those information in the code or just visualize them in the paraview?
The crack opening displacement and damage parameter (indicate the crack locations) are are stored as material properties, so you should be able to get those through getMaterialProperties API or look at the output Aux Variable in Paraview.

I want to use the cohesive force model to simulate the fracture propagation under fluid-structure coupling, but the model either does not propagate or does not converge.  I would like to know if the fluid field was taken into account when balancing forces within the crack. If fluid mechanics is considered, how to solve convergence, if not how to deal with the fluid mechanics balance in the fracture.

node.title: Multi-app System Run Sub App Every Other Time Step
node.bodyText: What would be the best way to be able to run sub-apps every nth timestep?

I would use Controls, the conditional enable ones
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Controls/index.html
I d probably bake the nth timestep logic into a ParsedFunction or a ParsedPostprocessor (which can be used in a ParsedFunction)
So would I set the enabled flag on the TransientMultiApp to be equal to the value of a ParsedFunctionControl block?

unfortunately that wont work, the ParsedFunctionControl is for THM simulations and we dont use it for enabling objects.
I would use a ParsedFunction inside a https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/controls/ConditionalFunctionEnableControl.html

Thanks. This seems to mostly work. It does the enable and disable, but it does not seem to work on the correct initial time step. Below is what I added...
[AuxVariables]
  [timesteps]
    family = SCALAR
    initial_condition = 0  
  []
[]

[AuxScalarKernels]
  [count_steps]
    type = FunctionScalarAux
    variable = timesteps
    execute_on = TIMESTEP_BEGIN
    function = fcount_steps
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [fcount_steps]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = 'a+1'
    vars = 'a'
    vals = 'timesteps'
  []
  [subapp_ctrl]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = 'a%5=0'
    vars = 'a'
    vals = 'timesteps'
  []
[]

[Controls]
  [disable]
      type = ConditionalFunctionEnableControl
      conditional_function = subapp_ctrl
      enable_objects = 'MultiApps::sub'
      execute_on = TIMESTEP_END 
  []
[]

What I was trying to have it do was have the subapp run every 5th timestep and it does on every one but the first run. Right now the subapp will run on the 8th, 13th and 18th timesteps. I can see the scalar outputs of the timestep variable increments correctly with time, but it appears that the ConditionalFunctionEnableControl is out of sync with the aux system updating the timesteps variable.
The 5th timestep isn't a critical number, it was just a value that would run often enough in the test while also clearly showing a break between runs in the log output.
Thanks!

Hello
I could see that. There's sort of an sequence of execution of objects before the updated value gets seen, 3 steps is a little excessive here. I would have expected maybe 1 or 2.
I would say we need a NumTimeSteps postprocessor. We dont have that. So let's use these two:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/TimeStepMaterial.html that provides a timestep material property
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/ElementExtremeMaterialProperty.html
then feed the PP in the ParsedFunction.
If you execute the postprocessor often enough, it will be up to date for the evaluation of the function done on step 5.
Guillaume

That method seems a bit cleaner to get the timesteps, but I can't seem to get the PP to execute often enough. If I set execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_BEGIN TIMESTEP_END' it now starts on step 7 and goes every 5 after that. But if I do execute_on = 'ALWAYS' the PP doesn't seem to update at all.
Postprocessor Values:
+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+
| time           | gap_distance   | gap_mm         | timestep_pp    |
+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+
|   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |
|   1.000000e+00 |   3.000000e-04 |   3.000000e-01 |   0.000000e+00 |
|   2.000000e+00 |   3.000000e-04 |   3.000000e-01 |   0.000000e+00 |
|   3.000000e+00 |   9.718305e-05 |   9.718305e-02 |   0.000000e+00 |
|   4.000000e+00 |   1.025832e-04 |   1.025832e-01 |   0.000000e+00 |
|   5.000000e+00 |   1.025832e-04 |   1.025832e-01 |   0.000000e+00 |
+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+

This is how I setup the material and PP
[timestep_pp]
      type = ElementExtremeMaterialProperty
      mat_prop = time_step
      value_type = max
      # execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_BEGIN TIMESTEP_END'
      execute_on = 'ALWAYS'
[]
[time]
    type = TimeStepMaterial
[]

I think a NumTimeSteps PostProcessor would be good to have, but I am thinking it will not solve the issue. I would still need to adjust the ParsedFunction to trigger earlier to account for the delay.

ALWAYS should no longer exist for postprocessors. Please do not use that, it was removed for a reason (not as often as always would suggest)
Step 7 is better I guess. I think I would understand 6. Since you start at 1 at the end of timestep 1, then I could see 5 at the end of timestep 5 being too late for the Control (which does not execute at the very end)
Would you be open to just doing this?
  [subapp_ctrl]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = '(a-2)%5=0'
    vars = 'a'
    vals = 'timesteps'
  []
[]

I know it s not super clean, but it should trigger on 5
Another thing would be to execute the control on timestep begin.

Ah ok.
Yeah, making the change like that shouldn't be an issue. Do you think it would be consistent with the offset? Or if I changed the number of steps to skip would I also need to change the a-2 to a different offset?
I would expect the offset and the frequency (currently 5) to be independent.

Ok thanks!
I will move forward with the PP approach since it requires less additions to the input file and update the offset.
Appreciate the help.

node.title: 1 test failing while running an example
node.bodyText:
While running an example with Pre-built moose, most tests are getting passed, a few are being skipped and "1 test is always failing" with whatever example I run.
Also, under the "ls $CONDA_PREFIX/moose/share/moose", I am unable to find 'heat_conduction'
I therefore tried running 'heat_transfer' and 'porous_flow' but even for them, 1 test is failing every time.
Does anyone have any idea what's happening?

Hello
For heat_conduction, that's the former name of the heat_transfer module. No need to try to run the heat_conduction tests.
Guillaume
